awd_titl_txt: IRES Track I: Shiraki International Multidisciplinary Undergraduate Research (SIMuR) Project
awd_abstract_narration:
The Shiraki International Multidisciplinary Undergraduate Research (SIMuR) project is a collaboration between faculty and students at three public universities (Bridgewater State University, University of California San Diego, and Ilia State University in Georgia) and the National Academy of Sciences of Georgia. The SIMuR project will engage U.S. undergraduate students in interdisciplinary research of historical and ongoing human-environmental interactions in the Shiraki Plateau in the southeastern part of the country of Georgia. The project will strengthen scientific knowledge, technical and leadership skills of a cohort of diverse, globally competent, and engaged young STEM researchers. This international research experience will embed students in a cross-country and cross-disciplinary research effort while getting them acquainted with the national specifics of this culturally-rich strategic region. SIMuR will increase STEM engagement and literacy in underserved communities in rural Georgia and the US, bringing advanced data science, visualization and spatial and temporal analysis concepts and technologies into this cross-country collaboration, thus improving the capacity of students and universities to address research problems of global significance.

Specifically, understanding the interplay of natural and anthropogenic factors in the history of human settlement on the Shiraki Plateau is a part of the interdisciplinary challenge of identifying and modeling impacts of human and environmental changes influencing the rise and decline of civilizations. With the goal of contributing to this developing body of knowledge, SIMuR will engage 15 undergraduate students from Bridgewater State University (5 students each year) in high-quality interdisciplinary research collaborations with Georgian peers and mentorship from an international group of experts in geological sciences, cyber-archaeology, computer engineering, information management, and data science. Participants will also engage in STEM outreach to underserved communities in southeastern Georgia and Massachusetts. Both the research and educational components of the project will build on a confluence of advanced technologies to clarify the several competing hypotheses of the depopulation of the Shiraki Plateau, the site of a recently discovered early civilization. The active reconsideration of the early human history of this area by the research community, and rapidly growing additional data from archaeological excavations and field observations in geology, hydrology, paleo-ecology and related fields, will make this an unprecedented opportunity for students to engage in the science debate, develop field research and analysis skills, and deepen their understanding of this rapidly developing culturally diverse area. By creating and disseminating findings in accessible online locations, the project will increase equitable access to authentic scientific data to scientists, educators, and underserved communities in US and throughout the world. Recruitment will focus on undergraduate students from groups traditionally underserved in STEM fields, low-income and first-generation college students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Shiraki International Multidisciplinary undergraduate Research (SIMuR) Project successfully demonstrated a new model for conducting undergraduate research projects in an international setting. Project PIs selected students for their potential to develop and lead interdisciplinary research projects related to the Shiraki Plateau in the country of Georgia. Altogether, this grant supported 14 undergraduate students from Bridgewater State University in Massachusetts who developed unique projects spanning the fields of archeology, geology, biology, computer science, and education. They collaborated with Bridgewater State faculty, faculty and graduate students from Ilia State University in Tbilisi, Georgia, and faculty from UC San Diego. Among their discoveries are 1) developing images of subterranean structures at several Late Bronze Age (approximately 3,000 years ago) archeological sites on the plateau using ground penetrating radar (GPR), 2) geologic evidence of ancient streams and a lake, supporting the hypothesis that there was more precipitation at this location during the Late Bronze Age than today, and 3) biologic evidence that the flora and fauna have drastically changed, from a forested environment during the Late Bronze Age to a semi-arid steppe environment today. Additionally, several projects were related to the creation of a virtual museum (called the Virtual Museum of the Archeology of the Southern Caucasus) in which artifacts collected from the plateau are scanned and 3D recreations of them are displayed. This museum is free and accessible to anyone with an internet connection. Other projects supported the development of a simulation of a Late Bronze Age settlement that, when ready, will allow viewers to wear 3D headsets and walk through a reconstruction of Didrui (one of the Shiraki sites) as it may have looked thousands of years ago. All of these projects have advanced our understanding of the environment and culture of the Shiraki Plateau, which, despite its location on the Silk Road, has remained understudied until recently.

An equally successful aspect of this project was the development of its student researchers. By putting them in a leadership role on their own projects, they learned and practiced many skills that aren’t usually part of a typical undergraduate curriculum. For example, they had to create a research topic and work with their faculty mentors to hone it into an achievable project. They also worked with their peers from other disciplines on collecting samples and data from the field, processing them in the lab, and analyzing the results. Throughout the project, they honed their scientific communication skills by presenting the results of their work in a variety of settings (scientific conferences; elementary, middle, and high schools; and community events), to different audiences (researchers, children, and the general public), and in different formats (posters, talks, activities). Finally, they developed cultural awareness and empathy by collaborating with Georgian peers and faculty, traveling to and within Georgia, and learning some Georgian words and phrases. These skills are important for developing future researchers and citizens who can work in increasingly diverse and global workplaces.
